## Overview of infectious disease model types

-   Infectious disease models can be classified in several ways:
    -   [Mathematical approach]{style="color:tomato; font-weight:bold;"}: mechanistic vs. phenomenological
    -   [Randomness]{style="color:tomato; font-weight:bold;"}: deterministic vs. stochastic
    -   [Time]{style="color:tomato; font-weight:bold;"}: discrete vs. continuous
    -   [Space]{style="color:tomato; font-weight:bold;"}: spatial vs. non-spatial
    -   [Population structure]{style="color:tomato; font-weight:bold;"}: homogeneous vs. heterogeneous

------------------------------------------------------------------------

-   The choice of model type depends on:
    -   [Research question]{style="color:tomato"} being addressed
    -   [Available data]{style="color:tomato"} and its quality
    -   [Computational resources]{style="color:tomato"} and time constraints
    -   [Expertise]{style="color:tomato"} of the modelling team
    -   [Intended audience]{style="color:tomato"} and use case

------------------------------------------------------------------------

## Mathematical approach: Mechanistic vs. Phenomenological

::::: columns
::: {.column width="50%"}
### Mechanistic models

-   Model the [underlying biological processes]{style="color:blue"} of disease transmission
-   Include explicit representations of:
    -   Host-pathogen interactions
    -   Disease natural history
    -   Population mixing patterns
:::

::: {.column width="50%"}
### Phenomenological models

-   Focus on [describing patterns]{style="color:orange"} in data
-   Do not explicitly model biological mechanisms
-   Often statistical in nature
:::
:::::

## Mathematical approach: Mechanistic vs. Phenomenological

::::: columns
::: {.column width="50%"}
### Mechanistic models

-   Examples: SIR, SEIR, agent-based models
:::

::: {.column width="50%"}
### Phenomenological models

-   Examples: curve fitting, time series models, regression models
:::
:::::

------------------------------------------------------------------------

### Mechanistic models: Advantages and disadvantages

::::: columns
::: {.column width="50%"}
**Advantages:**

\- Can provide [biological insights]{style="color:green"}

\- Allow testing of [intervention scenarios]{style="color:green"}

\-   Can extrapolate beyond observed data

\- Parameters often have [biological interpretation]{style="color:green"}
:::

::: {.column width="50%"}
**Disadvantages:**

\- Require [detailed knowledge]{style="color:red"} of biological processes

\- Can be [complex]{style="color:red"} to develop and validate

\- May require [extensive data]{style="color:red"} for parameterization

\- Computationally [expensive]{style="color:red"}
:::
:::::

------------------------------------------------------------------------

### Phenomenological models: Advantages and disadvantages

::::: columns
::: {.column width="50%"}
**Advantages:**

\- [Simpler]{style="color:green"} to develop and implement

\- Good for [short-term predictions]{style="color:green"}

\- Require [less detailed data]{style="color:green"}

\- Computationally [efficient]{style="color:green"}
:::

::: {.column width="50%"}
**Disadvantages:**

\- Limited [biological insight]{style="color:red"}

\- Poor [extrapolation]{style="color:red"} capabilities

\- Cannot easily test [interventions]{style="color:red"}

\- May not capture [underlying dynamics]{style="color:red"}
:::
:::::

------------------------------------------------------------------------

::: {.callout-important icon="false"}
### Discussion

Think of a recent epidemic (e.g., COVID-19, Mpox, Ebola). Which type of model would be more appropriate for:

1\. Understanding transmission mechanisms?

2\. Forecasting case numbers next week?

3\. Evaluating vaccination strategies?
:::

------------------------------------------------------------------------

## Deterministic vs. Stochastic models

::::: columns
::: {.column width="50%"}
### Deterministic models

-   [Same input]{style="color:blue"} always produces [same output]{style="color:blue"}
-   Use differential equations or difference equations
-   Represent [average behavior]{style="color:blue"} of the system
-   Examples: classical SIR/SEIR models
:::

::: {.column width="50%"}
### Stochastic models

-   Include [random variation]{style="color:orange"}
-   Same input can produce [different outputs]{style="color:orange"}
-   Account for uncertainty and chance events
-   Examples: stochastic SIR, branching processes
:::
:::::

------------------------------------------------------------------------

### When to use deterministic vs. stochastic models?

::::: columns
::: {.column width="50%"}
### Deterministic models

**Best for:**

\- [Large populations]{style="color:green"} (\>10,000)

\- Understanding [general trends]{style="color:green"}

\- [Parameter estimation]{style="color:green"}

\- When computational [efficiency]{style="color:green"} is important
:::

::: {.column width="50%"}
### Stochastic models

**Best for:**

\- [Small populations]{style="color:green"} (\<1,000)

\- [Early epidemic phases]{style="color:green"}

\- [Uncertainty quantification]{style="color:green"}

\- [Extinction events]{style="color:green"}
:::
:::::

------------------------------------------------------------------------

### When to use deterministic vs. stochastic models?

::::: columns
::: {.column width="50%"}
### Deterministic models

**Limitations:**

\- Cannot capture [fade-out]{style="color:red"} in small populations

\- No [uncertainty quantification]{style="color:red"}
:::

::: {.column width="50%"}
### Stochastic models

**Limitations:**

\- Computationally [intensive]{style="color:red"}

\- Require [multiple runs]{style="color:red"}

\- More complex to [implement]{style="color:red"}
:::
:::::

## Time: Discrete vs. Continuous models

::::: columns
::: {.column width="50%"}
### Discrete time models

-   Time progresses in [fixed steps]{style="color:blue"} (hours, days, weeks)
-   Use *difference equations*
-   Natural for [surveillance data]{style="color:blue"}
:::

::: {.column width="50%"}
### Continuous time models

-   Time flows [continuously]{style="color:orange"}
-   Use *differential equations*
-   Better for [theoretical analysis]{style="color:orange"}
:::
:::::

------------------------------------------------------------------------

## Time: Discrete vs. Continuous models

::::: columns
::: {.column width="50%"}
### Discrete time models

-   Examples: daily case counts, weekly reports

$$S_{t+1} = S_t - \beta S_t I_t$$
:::

::: {.column width="50%"}
### Continuous time models

-   Examples: classical epidemic models

$$\frac{dS}{dt} = -\beta S I$$
:::
:::::

------------------------------------------------------------------------

### Time scale considerations

-   [Disease natural history]{style="color:tomato"}:
    -   Acute diseases (days) → *discrete time* often sufficient
    -   Chronic diseases (years) → *continuous time* may be better

------------------------------------------------------------------------

-   [Data availability]{style="color:tomato"}:
    -   Daily surveillance data → *discrete time* natural
    -   Continuous monitoring → either approach possible

------------------------------------------------------------------------

-   [Research question]{style="color:tomato"}:
    -   Policy timing → *discrete time* practical
    -   Theoretical insights → *continuous time* elegant

## Spatial considerations

::::: columns
::: {.column width="50%"}
### Non-spatial (well-mixed) models

-   Assume [homogeneous mixing]{style="color:blue"}
-   All individuals have [equal contact]{style="color:blue"} probability
-   Simpler to analyze and implement
-   Good for [small, homogeneous]{style="color:blue"} populations
:::

::: {.column width="50%"}
### Spatial models

-   Account for [geographic structure]{style="color:orange"}
-   Include [movement patterns]{style="color:orange"}
-   Can model [local transmission]{style="color:orange"}
-   Important for [large-scale]{style="color:orange"} epidemics
:::
:::::

------------------------------------------------------------------------

::::: columns
::: {.column width="50%"}
### Non-spatial (well-mixed) models

-   Simpler to analyze and implement
-   Good for [small, homogeneous]{style="color:blue"} populations
:::

::: {.column width="50%"}
### Spatial models

-   Can model [local transmission]{style="color:orange"}
-   Important for [large-scale]{style="color:orange"} epidemics
:::
:::::

------------------------------------------------------------------------

-   [**Metapopulation models**]{style="color:tomato"}:
    -   Discrete patches connected by migration
    -   Good for cities/regions connected by travel
    
------------------------------------------------------------------------

-   [**Network models**]{style="color:tomato"}:
    -   Individuals as nodes, contacts as edges
    -   Can represent social or transportation networks

------------------------------------------------------------------------

-   [**Continuous space models**]{style="color:tomato"}:
    -   Individuals distributed in continuous space
    -   Include local transmission kernels

------------------------------------------------------------------------

## Population structure: Homogeneous vs. Heterogeneous

::::: columns
::: {.column width="50%"}
### Homogeneous models

-   All individuals are [identical]{style="color:blue"}
-   Same [contact rates]{style="color:blue"}
-   Same [susceptibility]{style="color:blue"}
-   Simpler to analyze
:::

::: {.column width="50%"}
### Heterogeneous models

-   Account for [individual differences]{style="color:orange"}:
    -   Age groups
    -   Risk behaviors
    -   Vaccination status
    -   Geographic location
-   More realistic but complex
:::
:::::

------------------------------------------------------------------------

### Common types of heterogeneity

-   [**Age structure**]{style="color:tomato"}: Different contact patterns and susceptibility by age
-   [**Risk groups**]{style="color:tomato"}: High-risk vs. low-risk populations
-   [**Behavioral differences**]{style="color:tomato"}: Compliance with interventions

------------------------------------------------------------------------

-   [**Immunity status**]{style="color:tomato"}: Vaccinated, previously infected, naive
-   [**Geographic**]{style="color:tomato"}: Urban vs. rural, different regions

------------------------------------------------------------------------

## Network models

::::: columns
::: {.column width="60%"}
-   Represent individuals as [nodes]{style="color:tomato"}
-   Contacts/relationships as [edges]{style="color:tomato"}
-   Can capture:
    -   Social networks
    -   Sexual networks
    -   Transportation networks
    -   Hospital networks
:::

::: {.column width="40%"}
![Examples of network models. Source: [Danon et al., 2010](10.1155/2011/284909)](images/network_models.png)
:::
:::::

------------------------------------------------------------------------

### Network model advantages

-   Capture [realistic contact patterns]{style="color:green"}
-   Can model [targeted interventions]{style="color:green"} (e.g., contact tracing)
-   Account for [superspreading]{style="color:green"} events
-   Useful for [outbreak investigation]{style="color:green"}

### Network model challenges

-   Require [detailed contact data]{style="color:red"}
-   Computationally [intensive]{style="color:red"}
-   Network structure may be [unknown]{style="color:red"} or [time-varying]{style="color:red"}

## Agent-based models (ABMs)

-   Model [individual agents]{style="color:tomato"} and their interactions
-   Each agent has:
    -   Individual characteristics
    -   Behavioral rules
    -   Interaction patterns
    
------------------------------------------------------------------------

## Agent-based models (ABMs)

-   System behavior [emerges]{style="color:blue"} from individual interactions
-   Very flexible but computationally intensive

------------------------------------------------------------------------

### Agent-based model applications

-   [**Household transmission**]{style="color:tomato"}: Model within-household spread
-   [**School closures**]{style="color:tomato"}: Impact on different age groups
-   [**Behavioral responses**]{style="color:tomato"}: How people change behavior during epidemics

------------------------------------------------------------------------

### Agent-based model applications

-   [**Contact tracing**]{style="color:tomato"}: Effectiveness of different strategies
-   [**Vaccination campaigns**]{style="color:tomato"}: Optimal distribution strategies

------------------------------------------------------------------------

## Summary: Choosing the right model type

-   [**Start simple**]{style="color:tomato"}: Begin with the simplest model that addresses your question
-   [**Add complexity gradually**]{style="color:tomato"}: Only when justified by data or research needs
-   [**Consider your audience**]{style="color:tomato"}: Policymakers may prefer simpler, more interpretable models
-   [**Validate carefully**]{style="color:tomato"}: More complex models require more validation
-   [**Document assumptions**]{style="color:tomato"}: Be explicit about model limitations

------------------------------------------------------------------------

### Common model progression

1.  [**Homogeneous compartmental**]{style="color:blue"} (SIR/SEIR) → understanding basic dynamics
2.  [**Add heterogeneity**]{style="color:blue"} → age groups, risk groups
3.  [**Add spatial structure**]{style="color:blue"} → metapopulation, networks
4.  [**Add stochasticity**]{style="color:blue"} → uncertainty quantification
5.  [**Individual-based**]{style="color:blue"} → complex behaviors, interventions
